Mar 16

Each Top Player’s Defining Moment — Part IV: Cream of the Crop

Welcome to the final stretch as we barrel down the lane and then dunk this one home Russell Westbrook style. Speaking of Russell Westbrook.

Come in, sit down by the fire, get comfortable. Do not touch the Geiger Counter, I’m keeping it here until Russell Westbrook comes over. It’s for a science experiment. Trust me.

Charting the most defining moments of a player’s career is hard (pats self on back steadily), especially when the player’s career isn’t over. I’m sure in years to come I will regress back to this piece of work and think to myself, what was I thinking. Like that time I picked Michigan State in my bracket last year and promptly burned everything down. If I had a crystal ball, I’d safely predict some of these, like let’s say Russell Westbrook saves the planet from an alien invasion simply by dunking on armies of extra terrestrials. Or that time… You know, let’s just get through this.

Each Top Player’s Defining Moment — Part III: The Almost There’s
We’re in the final stretch so let’s talk about that time that Blake Griffin fricasseed a defender.16winsaring.com

Chris Paul — Point GAWD

If you were to put Chris Paul in a helicopter and then drop him off at a deserted island before flying back, he’d be waiting for you safely at home when you stepped through your front door. He is a master of angles with a precision of a mathematician and I would 100% include him on any team that is trying to calculate the correct angle at which to blow up an asteroid to bounce it off its trajectory towards Earth. Paul has made a career of inventing space where there was none and creating shots for both himself and his teammates. His mid-range pull-up jumper is the third-deadliest substance known to man shortly after botulinum toxin and snake venom. His career has been defined by determination to win at any cost. He is literally the human caption of every Instagram athlete photo caption.

Unfortunately for Paul, with that increased grit comes something else. He is an expert line-stepper who manages to consistently talk the ear off his opponents, teammates, referees, ball-boys, concession stand operators in the third tier of the Staples Center and I imagine anyone else within a 300 meter vicinity of him. Yet, despite all of that mental “toughness” Paul’s career defining ability is to go down as if he has been hit by a jump jet at full speed at the slightest touch. So it’s only fitting that…

Giannis Antetokounmpo — The Human Version of that Thing Godzilla Fought

I am fairly sure that years from now when Greece once again becomes relevant to human civilization we will venture into the islands and discover a long-abandoned human genetics lab. In it, a variety of radioactive insects were quietly bred to bite each other before biting Giannis and turning him into the definitive proof that pterodactyls are actually real. It’s really nice that he is able to keep Greek Mythology of super humans alive for this long in the NBA.

His true ability however is to accelerate down a lane and then pick a point at which to pick up his dribble, normally three meters before any normal human being would even contemplate this, and lift off. Ever since arriving in the NBA, Antetokounmpo has perfected the Euro step, which I once saw him perform from the parking lot of the BMO Harris Bradley Center. What’s even more impressive, is that despite taking off from another dimension Giannis does not waste time on that weak lay-up shit.

Jimmy Butler — The Dark Horse Contender

Here’s the thing about Jimmy Butler. It’s hard to pinpoint where exactly his boiling point is. Having played most of his career with personalities such as Derrick Rose and Dwyane Wade, Butler is the personification of “do your job” guy. You know in every assassin or action movie you come to a scene where a group of guys decide to terrorize an enclosed space, usually full of people. They casually pick a fight with literally everyone in that space until they arrive at the quiet guy. The quiet guy doesn’t say anything as he sits in the corner drinking his whiskey yet they insist to try and get the best out of him. That is until the quiet guy goes all Steven Seagal in A Time To Kill and leaves a room full of limbs in his wake. Jimmy Butler is the quiet guy.

Stephen Curry — The Church Boy

Steph Curry drains dagger threes with the casual nonchalance of John Wick rampaging through the architectural sights of Rome. He has perfected, distilled, cooked and refined the three-point shot formula and has managed to do it with the most IDGAF approach imaginable. Watching Steph Curry enter the building you realize that not a single spot on the floor is off-limits for his heat seeking missile launching ability. Granted, he has cooled off lately, but when he is in play, literally every place on the court is sizzling hot.

Steph Curry is as casual as the older brother beating his little siblings in basketball because they haven’t fully yet developed motor skills. Except that he’s not the older brother. Golden State is. Having assembled the Voltron of basketball, Mark 2.0, the Warriors spent most of the past to season simply searching for a challenge and letting complacency set in. It’s easy to open up a 200 mph romp in a Ferrari, try doing it in a Volkswagen (I see you Pop, taking that old junker to the shop for another 50+ win season). As such, here is an alternative suggestion to file under the AHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA, man, you thought?!

Anthony Davis — Actual Godzilla, Maybe

You gotta Love (capital L) Anthony Davis, the man who laid the foundation for the unicorn renaissance. Also, if you allow me to digress, the unicorn moniker is reserved for something that is unique, original and never seen in the wild. Over the past year the pundits have branded at least 5 players with it. It’s like staring at 5 identical brothers and saying that they’re one of a kind unique each and every one of them. Anyways, where was I?

Oh yes, Anthony Davis, or what happens when you put uranium into drinking water. He has exploded onto the scene, slowly refining the game he acquired as a young guard before his gargantuan growth spurt. His steady rise is in many ways due to the fact that there is literally nothing he can’t do. Nothing. Nada. If you were to tell me that Anthony Davis cured cancer tomorrow, I’d probably initially believe you (while still googling to confirm). As such, his best performances come at the time when he is posting numbers that look like latitude coordinates for a buried treasure.

Kevin Durant — Not Nice, But Soft

Remember that stage of Kevin Durant’s career where he tried to prove to everyone that he was hardened and tough? All of those Foot Locker commercials that tried really hard to step away from the image of Soft Kevin? Yeah, how did that work out.

Kevin Durant is one of the deadliest humans on this planet with a basketball in his hands. If there is an angle that is mathematically possible on the basketball court, he can score from it. Left, right, two, three, fifteen. You name it. He deserves a highlight, he deserves a highlight that is pure and good and soft and all things basketball just like he is. But he also left. He left OKC after this:

And as such, that will hang over him until he wins a chip with GSW. Possibly until he wins two. Maybe three. That’s what it took for all of us to forgive LeBron for the Decision.

Kawhi Leonard — Mark 4.0

Man, the latest software update to the Kawhigorithm is terrifying. I imagine Kawhi does every single thing with the definitive efficiency he plays basketball with. Brushing his teeth? 32 precise motions for each tooth. Pumping gas? He knows precisely when to stop when his tank is full. Making a peanut butter and jelly sandwich? The distribution is so perfect that each of your taste-buds automatically receives equal amount of food and enters nirvana.

Despite the annual update to software, which increased his numerous offensive capabilities, Kawhi Leonard will always be defined by his defense. Given the choice between having Kawhi guard me for 48 minutes or spending an full day in a torture chamber, I’m going with option B. Kawhi’s defense to basketball players is what Dementors are to pure and an unabashed goodness of this world. He drains it. Kawhi Leonard takes no pleasure in what he does, and neither will you. So here is LeBron James, a literal Greek God that has somehow fooled every single person on Earth that he is human, reacting to Leonard entering the game to guard him.

James Harden — The Bearded One

The simple joke here is to play James Harden defensive videos. The more complicated joke is to play a 2 hours video of James Harden shooting free throws because I do not have a single shadow of a doubt that he has spent over 2 hours of his career shooting free throws on national television. The no-joke way to define James Harden is this: A myriad of drives and change of speed moves that lure you into a different dimension as he bullies his way to the hoop past your non-responsive flailing body.

Russell Westbrook — OH MY GOD HE DID WHAT AGAIN NOW AGAHSFASFSAF?!

Russell Westbrook has no off-switch. Russell Westbrook’s idea of a leisurely Sunday stroll through the Farmer’s Market is conquering that Farmer’s Market and then lining up all his new faithful subjects so he could dunk on them at full speed. Russell Westbrook’s resting heart rate is 135. Russell Westbrook has never in his life take a cold shower because the water automatically reaches boiling temperature and evaporates when hitting his body. Russell Westbrook plays basketball as if he is Batman and every thing else in his vicinity (including players, refs, shot clocks, basketballs, rims, innocent bystanders) are the mugger that killed his family.

Russell Westbrook is the greatest show on Earth — the Person. He only has two modes of operation: rampage and Mad Max: Fury Road chase scene. Anything in between and it does not compute. Watching Russell Westbrook play basketball makes me feel like I never want to do anything with Russell Westbrook ever. I feel like if I beat him in Uno I would receive threatening letters and post-cards until I played him again. Worse, I think he may not let me out of the house until I play him again. Russell Westbrook is holding basketball hostage and basketball is slowly developing Stockholm Syndrome. If we could play with three basketballs, Russell Westbrook would demand all three and then also rebound both of his missed shots simultaneously.

Russell Westbrook has no off switch. That is his definitive feature.

LeBron James — Human?

It’s not that LeBron James has been put on this Earth to play basketball, it’s more that we were all put here that there would be eye witnesses of LeBron James, God’s most perfect creation, playing basketball. The simple fact that James has been this good for this long is scientifically absurd. I imagine in a 100 years when they dig LeBron James out of an iceberg, scientists of the future will have this conversation.

“Dear God, this can’t be… you don’t think he still operates?”
“I don’t know, but we need to find out.”
*LeBron thaws out and proceeds to dunk on everyone while orchestrating complex daytime soap opera scenarios to keep himself entertained*
“Dear God, what have we done!”

Due to his unnatural longevity, we have a catalog of LeBron moments to choose from. It could be The Decision, that fateful time he got some really bad PR advice. His promise to win multiple championships. His first Championship. His return to Cleveland. The Block. The SHIP FOR THE LAND. The continued wrangling of J.R. Smith — the Unexplained Human Phenomenon. Or all of the above.

I would like to however present a wildcard moment. A moment that defines LeBron the person not because it’s indicative of his all-encompassing success, but LeBron the super petty human being who is amazingly good at basketball and you should never forget it.

You can see all of his anger, all of his ire, all of his skill concentrate on a singular goal — bopping it on Draymond Green’s head. Having put with all the talk, all the criticism, all the behind-the-back jabs his whole career, LeBron has never given us any less than the full of him. And when he’s given us all of that, he still wants to give us more. It’s probably for the best that dunk missed because if it didn’t I think Draymond Green would be declared dead on the spot and LeBron James would be in jail for manslaughter on national television. And that would rob us of so many more potential LeBron defining moments.

Each Top Player’s Defining Moment — Part II: The Misfits
In part II of the series we look at NBA misfits and what makes them conspicuously unique.16winsaring.com

If you ever wanted to have a burning basketball (or not so much) question answered, deconstructed, decoded and then turned into a weird metaphor about superheroes or space aliens you can email those questions to basketball@armchairsociety.com and guess what, I’m going to take care of that for you.
